item.title: RL's Deadly Triad Meets Optimization
item.description:
\( \newcommand{\phit}{\phi_t} \newcommand{\phinext}{\phi_{t+1}} \newcommand{\enext}{\ebf_{s_{t+1}}} \newcommand{\et}{\ebf_{s_t}} \newcommand{\gradV}{\nabla_{\theta} V_{\theta}} \newcommand{\V}{V_{\theta}} \newcommand{\snext}{s_{t+1}} \newcommand{\tstar}{\theta^\star} \newcommand{\itmtx}{(\Ibf - \eta \Abf)} \newcommand{\AMC}{\Abf_{\text{MC}}} \newcommand{\Aon}{\Abf_{\text{on}}} \newcommand{\Atab}{\Abf_{\text{tab}}} \newcommand{\dpi}{d_{\pi}} \newcommand{\Ppi}{P_{\pi}} \newcommand{\Tpi}{\Tcal_{\pi}} \)

The unsavory combination of function approximation, off-policy learning, and bootstrapping, or the so-called “deadly triad” of reinforcement learning, has a status approaching that of folklore for its ability to induce instability in even the simplest of systems. While likely a household name among RL enthusiasts, I’ve seen surprisingly little discussion on its origins or first principles. I made this post to shed light on the deadly triad from the perspective of traditional optimization theory, with the goal of demonstrating that the underlying principles are nothing more exotic than well-established convergence guarantees for dynamical systems.
